text: VI The next morning brought Mr. Frank Churchill again .
text_tokenized: VI The next morning brought Mr. Frank Churchill again .

text: He came with Mrs. Weston , to whom and to Highbury he seemed to take very cordially .
text_tokenized: He came with Mrs. Weston , to whom and to Highbury he seemed to take very cordially .

text: He had been sitting with her , it appeared , most companionably at home , till her usual hour of exercise ; and on being desired to chuse their walk , immediately fixed on Highbury.--"He did not doubt there being very pleasant walks in every direction , but if left to him , he should always chuse the same .

text: Emma had hardly expected them : for Mr. Weston , who had called in for half a minute , in order to hear that his son was very handsome , knew nothing of their plans ; and it was an agreeable surprize to her , therefore , to perceive them walking up to the house together , arm in arm
text_tokenized: Emma had hardly expected them : for Mr. Weston , who had called in for half a minute , in order to hear that his son was very handsome , knew nothing of their plans ; and it was an agreeable surprize to her , therefore , to perceive them walking up to the house together , arm in arm

text: She was wanting to see him again , and especially to see him in company with Mrs. Weston , upon his behaviour to whom her opinion of him was to depend .
text_tokenized: She was wanting to see him again , and especially to see him in company with Mrs. Weston , upon his behaviour to whom her opinion of him was to depend .

text: If he were deficient there , nothing should make amends for it .
text_tokenized: If he were deficient there , nothing should make amends for it .

text: But on seeing them together , she became perfectly satisfied .
text_tokenized: But on seeing them together , she became perfectly satisfied .

text: It was not merely in fine words or hyperbolical compliment that he paid his duty ; nothing could be more proper or pleasing than his whole manner to her -- nothing could more agreeably denote his wish of considering her as a friend and securing her affection .
text_tokenized: It was not merely in fine words or hyperbolical compliment that he paid his duty ; nothing could be more proper or pleasing than his whole manner to her -- nothing could more agreeably denote his wish of considering her as a friend and securing her affection .

text: And there was time enough for Emma to form a reasonable judgment , as their visit included all the rest of the morning . They were all three walking about together for an hour or two-- first round the shrubberies of Hartfield , and afterwards in Highbury . He was delighted with every thing ; admired Hartfield sufficiently for Mr. Woodhouse 's ear ; and when their going farther was resolved on , confessed his wish to be made acquainted with the whole village , and found matter of commendation and interest much oftener than Emma could have supposed .
text_tokenized: And there was time enough for Emma to form a reasonable judgment , as their visit included all the rest of the morning . They were all three walking about together for an hour or two-- first round the shrubberies of Hartfield , and afterwards in Highbury . He was delighted with every thing ; admired Hartfield sufficiently for Mr. Woodhouse 's ear ; and when their going farther was resolved on , confessed his wish to be made acquainted with the whole village , and found matter of commendation and interest much oftener than Emma could have supposed .

text: Some of the objects of his curiosity spoke very amiable feelings .
text_tokenized: Some of the objects of his curiosity spoke very amiable feelings .

text: He begged to be shewn the house which his father had lived in so long , and which had been the home of his father 's father ; and on recollecting that an old woman who had nursed him was still living , walked in quest of her cottage from one end of the street to the other ; and though in some points of pursuit or observation there was no positive merit , they shewed , altogether , a good - will towards Highbury in general , which must be very like a merit to those he was with .
text_tokenized: He begged to be shewn the house which his father had lived in so long , and which had been the home of his father 's father ; and on recollecting that an old woman who had nursed him was still living , walked in quest of her cottage from one end of the street to the other ; and though in some points of pursuit or observation there was no positive merit , they shewed , altogether , a good - will towards Highbury in general , which must be very like a merit to those he was with .

text: Emma watched and decided , that with such feelings as were now shewn , it could not be fairly supposed that he had been ever voluntarily absenting himself ; that he had not been acting a part , or making a parade of insincere professions ; and that Mr. Knightley certainly had not done him justice .
text_tokenized: Emma watched and decided , that with such feelings as were now shewn , it could not be fairly supposed that he had been ever voluntarily absenting himself ; that he had not been acting a part , or making a parade of insincere professions ; and that Mr. Knightley certainly had not done him justice .

text: Their first pause was at the Crown Inn , an inconsiderable house , though the principal one of the sort , where a couple of pair of post - horses were kept , more for the convenience of the neighbourhood than from any run on the road ; and his companions had not expected to be detained by any interest excited there ; but in passing it they gave the history of the large room visibly added ; it had been built many years ago for a ball - room , and while the neighbourhood had been in a particularly populous , dancing state , had been occasionally used as such;--but such brilliant days had long passed away , and now the highest purpose for which it was ever wanted was to accommodate a whist club established among the gentlemen and half - gentlemen of the place . He was immediately interested .

text: Its character as a ball - room caught him ; and instead of passing on , he stopt for several minutes at the two superior sashed windows which were open , to look in and contemplate its capabilities , and lament that its original purpose should have ceased .

text_tokenized: No , it was long enough , broad enough , handsome enough .

text: They ought to have balls there at least every fortnight through the winter .
text_tokenized: They ought to have balls there at least every fortnight through the winter .

text: Why had not Miss Woodhouse revived the former good old days of the room?--She who could do any thing in Highbury !
text_tokenized: Why had not Miss Woodhouse revived the former good old days of the room?--She who could do any thing in Highbury !

text: The want of proper families in the place , and the conviction that none beyond the place and its immediate environs could be tempted to attend , were mentioned ; but he was not satisfied .
text_tokenized: The want of proper families in the place , and the conviction that none beyond the place and its immediate environs could be tempted to attend , were mentioned ; but he was not satisfied .

text: He could not be persuaded that so many good - looking houses as he saw around him , could not furnish numbers enough for such a meeting ; and even when particulars were given and families described , he was still unwilling to admit that the inconvenience of such a mixture would be any thing , or that there would be the smallest difficulty in every body 's returning into their proper place the next morning .

text: He seemed to have all the life and spirit , cheerful feelings , and social inclinations of his father , and nothing of the pride or reserve of Enscombe .

text: At last he was persuaded to move on from the front of the Crown ; and being now almost facing the house where the Bateses lodged , Emma recollected his intended visit the day before , and asked him if he had paid it . " Yes , oh ! yes"--he replied ; " I was just going to mention it .

text: As it was , I was only betrayed into paying a most unreasonable visit .
text_tokenized: As it was , I was only betrayed into paying a most unreasonable visit .

text: Ten minutes would have been all that was necessary , perhaps all that was proper ; and I had told my father I should certainly be at home before him -- but there was no getting away , no pause ; and , to my utter astonishment , I found , when he ( finding me nowhere else ) joined me there at last , that I had been actually sitting with them very nearly three - quarters of an hour .

text: The good lady had not given me the possibility of escape before .

text: " And how did you think Miss Fairfax looking ? " " Ill , very ill -- that is , if a young lady can ever be allowed to look ill . But the expression is hardly admissible , Mrs. Weston , is it ?
text_tokenized: " And how did you think Miss Fairfax looking ? " " Ill , very ill -- that is , if a young lady can ever be allowed to look ill . But the expression is hardly admissible , Mrs. Weston , is it ?

text: Ladies can never look ill . And , seriously , Miss Fairfax is naturally so pale , as almost always to give the appearance of ill health.-- A most deplorable want of complexion .
text_tokenized: Ladies can never look ill . And , seriously , Miss Fairfax is naturally so pale , as almost always to give the appearance of ill health.-- A most deplorable want of complexion .

text: Emma would not agree to this , and began a warm defence of Miss Fairfax 's complexion .
text_tokenized: Emma would not agree to this , and began a warm defence of Miss Fairfax 's complexion .

text: " It was certainly never brilliant , but she would not allow it to have a sickly hue in general ; and there was a softness and delicacy in her skin which gave peculiar elegance to the character of her face . "
text_tokenized: " It was certainly never brilliant , but she would not allow it to have a sickly hue in general ; and there was a softness and delicacy in her skin which gave peculiar elegance to the character of her face . "

text: He listened with all due deference ; acknowledged that he had heard many people say the same -- but yet he must confess , that to him nothing could make amends for the want of the fine glow of health .
text_tokenized: He listened with all due deference ; acknowledged that he had heard many people say the same -- but yet he must confess , that to him nothing could make amends for the want of the fine glow of health .

text: Where features were indifferent , a fine complexion gave beauty to them all ; and where they were good , the effect was -- fortunately he need not attempt to describe what the effect was . " Well , " said Emma , " there is no disputing about taste.--At least you admire her except her complexion .

text: If it be not inconvenient to you , pray let us go in , that I may prove myself to belong to the place , to be a true citizen of Highbury . I must buy something at Ford 's .
text_tokenized: If it be not inconvenient to you , pray let us go in , that I may prove myself to belong to the place , to be a true citizen of Highbury . I must buy something at Ford 's .

text: You were very popular before you came , because you were Mr. Weston 's son -- but lay out half a guinea at Ford 's , and your popularity will stand upon your own virtues . " They went in ; and while the sleek , well - tied parcels of " Men 's Beavers " and " York Tan " were bringing down and displaying on the counter , he said--"But I beg your pardon , Miss Woodhouse , you were speaking to me , you were saying something at the very moment of this burst of my _ amor _ _ patriae _ .

text: I am excessively fond of music , but without the smallest skill or right of judging of any body 's performance.--I have been used to hear her 's admired ; and I remember one proof of her being thought to play well:--a man , a very musical man , and in love with another woman -- engaged to her -- on the point of marriage-- would yet never ask that other woman to sit down to the instrument , if the lady in question could sit down instead -- never seemed to like to hear one if he could hear the other .

text: Intimacy between Miss Fairfax and me is quite out of the question .

text: I have no reason to think ill of her -- not the least -- except that such extreme and perpetual cautiousness of word and manner , such a dread of giving a distinct idea about any body , is apt to suggest suspicions of there being something to conceal . " He perfectly agreed with her : and after walking together so long , and thinking so much alike , Emma felt herself so well acquainted with him , that she could hardly believe it to be only their second meeting . He was not exactly what she had expected ; less of the man of the world in some of his notions , less of the spoiled child of fortune , therefore better than she had expected .

text: His ideas seemed more moderate-- his feelings warmer .
text_tokenized: His ideas seemed more moderate-- his feelings warmer .

text: She was particularly struck by his manner of considering Mr. Elton 's house , which , as well as the church , he would go and look at , and would not join them in finding much fault with .
text_tokenized: She was particularly struck by his manner of considering Mr. Elton 's house , which , as well as the church , he would go and look at , and would not join them in finding much fault with .

text: No , he could not believe it a bad house ; not such a house as a man was to be pitied for having
text_tokenized: No , he could not believe it a bad house ; not such a house as a man was to be pitied for having

text: If it were to be shared with the woman he loved , he could not think any man to be pitied for having that house .
text_tokenized: If it were to be shared with the woman he loved , he could not think any man to be pitied for having that house .

text: There must be ample room in it for every real comfort .
text_tokenized: There must be ample room in it for every real comfort .

text: The man must be a blockhead who wanted more . Mrs. Weston laughed , and said he did not know what he was talking about .
text_tokenized: The man must be a blockhead who wanted more . Mrs. Weston laughed , and said he did not know what he was talking about .

text: Used only to a large house himself , and without ever thinking how many advantages and accommodations were attached to its size
text_tokenized: Used only to a large house himself , and without ever thinking how many advantages and accommodations were attached to its size

text: , he could be no judge of the privations inevitably belonging to a small one .
text_tokenized: , he could be no judge of the privations inevitably belonging to a small one .

text: But Emma , in her own mind , determined that he _ did _ know what he was talking about , and that he shewed a very amiable inclination to settle early in life , and to marry , from worthy motives .
text_tokenized: But Emma , in her own mind , determined that he _ did _ know what he was talking about , and that he shewed a very amiable inclination to settle early in life , and to marry , from worthy motives .

text: He might not be aware of the inroads on domestic peace to be occasioned by no housekeeper 's room , or a bad butler 's pantry , but no doubt he did perfectly feel that Enscombe could not make him happy , and that whenever he were attached , he would willingly give up much of wealth to be allowed an early establishment .
